Use actionable verbs that describe what you want to do - Be specific - Add R to the search query - Add the name of the R package name to the search query - Scroll through the top 5 results (don't just pick the first) **Example: "How to remove a legend from a plot in R ggplot2"** ## Stack Overflow ::: {.incremental} :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="47.5%"} **What is it?** - The biggest support network for (coding) problems - Can be intimidating at first - Up-vote system ::: ::: {.column width="5%"} ::: ::: {.column width="47.5%"} **Workflow** - First, briefly read the question that was posted - Then, read the answer marked as "correct" - Then, read one or two more answers with high votes - Then, check out the "Linked" posts - Always give credit for the solution ::: :::: ::: ## Give credit ![](img/lec-02/stack-overflow-share-1.png) ## Give credit ![](img/lec-02/stack-overflow-share-2.png) ## Give credit {.smaller} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="5-6"} ggplot(data = global_waste_data_kg_year, mapping = aes(x = income_id, y = capita_kg_year, color = income_id)) + ## Remove legend ref: https://stackoverflow.com/a/35622358/6816220 theme(legend.position = "none") ``` ::: ## Other sources for help :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} - Our Google Space for the course - RStudio Community Forum: https://community.rstudio.com/ - Documentation websites: https://dplyr.tidyverse.org/ - Twitter community: [#rstats](https://twitter.com/search?q=%23rstats&src=typd) ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ![](img/lec-02/welcome_to_rstats_twitter.png) ::: :::: ::: aside Artwork by [@allison_horst](https://www.allisonhorst.com/) ::: ## Minimal reproducible example (reprex) - Needed when asking questions online - Good support information: https://www.tidyverse.org/help/#reprex ## . {background-image="img/lec-02/code_hero.jpg" background-size="contain"} ::: aside Artwork by [@allison_horst](https://www.allisonhorst.com/) ::: ## Learning Objectives (for this week) ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} lobj1 <- readr::read_csv(here::here("data/tbl-02-cven5837-ss23-learning-objectives.csv")) |> dplyr::filter(week == params$week) |> dplyr::pull(learning_objectives) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Rows: 22 Columns: 4 ── Column specification ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────── Delimiter: "," chr (2): title, learning_objectives dbl (1): week dttm (1): date ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data. ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message. ``` ::: ::: 1. Learners can describe the four main aesthetic mappings that can be used to visualise data using the ggplot2 R Package. 1. Learners can control the colour scaling applied to a plot using colour as an aesthetic mapping. 1. Learners can compare three different geoms and their use case. 1. Learners can apply a theme to control font types and sizes within a plot. 1. Learners can apply 12 principles for data organisation in spreadsheets in the layout of a collected dataset. # Exploratory Data Analysis with `ggplot2` {background-color="#0F4C81"} ## R Package `ggplot2` :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} - **ggplot2** is tidyverse's data visualization package - `gg` in `ggplot2` stands for Grammar of Graphics - Inspired by the book **Grammar of Graphics** by Leland Wilkinson - **Documentation:** https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/ - **Book**: https://ggplot2-book.org ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ![](img/lec-02/ggplot2-part-of-tidyverse.png) ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} #knitr::include_graphics(here::here("slides/img/lec-02/ggplot2-part-of-tidyverse.png")) ``` ::: ::: :::: ::: {.aside} Slide adapted from datasciencebox.org ::: ## Code structure - `ggplot()` is the main function in ggplot2 - Plots are constructed in layers - Structure of the code for plots can be summarized as ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(data = [dataset], mapping = aes(x = [x-variable], y = [y-variable])) + geom_xxx() + other options ``` ::: ## Code structure {auto-animate="true"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lec-02-visualisation_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-7-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Code structure {auto-animate="true"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(data = gapminder_yr_2007) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lec-02-visualisation_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-8-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Code structure {auto-animate="true"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(data = gapminder_yr_2007, mapping = aes()) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lec-02-visualisation_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-9-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Code structure {auto-animate="true"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(data = gapminder_yr_2007, mapping = aes(x = continent, y = lifeExp)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lec-02-visualisation_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-10-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Code structure {auto-animate="true"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(data = gapminder_yr_2007, mapping = aes(x = continent, y = lifeExp)) + geom_boxplot() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lec-02-visualisation_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-11-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Code structure {auto-animate="true"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(data = gapminder_yr_2007, mapping = aes(x = continent, y = lifeExp)) + geom_boxplot() + theme_minimal() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lec-02-visualisation_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-12-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## non-negative - whole numbers - e.g. number of students, roll of a dice **continuous variables** - infinite number of values - also dates and times - e.g. length, weight, size ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ### non-numerical **categorical variables** - finite number of values - distinct groups (e.g. EU countries, continents) - **ordinal** if levels have natural ordering (e.g. week days, school grades) ::: :::: ::: ## {background-image="https://d33wubrfki0l68.cloudfront.net/1e7033393a2c70dc1255c5d0f1c563e945519251/61035/img/evol-ggplot/evol-ggplot-1.gif" background-size="contain"} ::: {.aside} **Tutorial:** https://www.cedricscherer.com/2019/05/17/the-evolution-of-a-ggplot-ep.-1/ ::: ## data-to-viz.com {background-iframe="https://www.data-to-viz.com/" background-interactive="true"} # Data Collection Tools {background-color="#0F4C81"} ## Data Collection Tools - Questionnaires for survey based data - Spreadsheets for manual experimental/observational data - Sensors for automated near real-time data ## Survey tools **Commonly used in the Global Engineering and Development sector** - KOBO Toolbox - mWater - OpenDataKit ## Data Organisation in Spreadsheets ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} knitr::include_graphics("img/lec-02/data-org-paper.png") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](img/lec-02/data-org-paper.png){width=782} ::: ::: ::: {.aside} Jorunal: The American Statistician, [Screenshot taken on 2022-03-23](https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/00031305.2017.1375989?src=) ::: ## Data Organisation in Spreadsheets Read the paper (it's part of your homework), but you can also: - Go through the annotated slides: https://kbroman.org/Talk_DataOrg/dataorg_notes.pdf - Watch Karl Broman give the talk (02:36 to 45:00): https://youtu.be/t74E0a90gkA?t=156 - Read the content on a website: https://kbroman.org/dataorg/ ## But, especially apply it to your data
